content.title: Cauda Equina Syndrome
content.summary: Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is a neurosurgical emergency caused by compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the conus medullaris. It presents with saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder dysfunction, lower extremity weakness, and low back pain. Urgent surgical decompression within 24 hours provides optimal bladder recovery, with even earlier surgery (6-12 hours) recommended for complete CES.
key_points: Surgical emergency: Decompression within 24 hours for optimal bladder recovery; earlier for complete CES
Classic presentation: Saddle anesthesia + urinary retention/incontinence + bilateral leg weakness
Most common cause: Large central disc herniation at L4-L5 or L5-S1
MRI lumbar spine is diagnostic; order emergently if CES suspected
Incomplete CES (urinary difficulties) has better prognosis than complete CES (retention)
content.statement: Cauda equina syndrome requires emergent recognition and surgical decompression within 24-48 hours to preserve bowel, bladder, and motor function in this devastating but potentially reversible condition.

explanation.intuition: The cauda equina ('horse's tail') is where the spinal cord ends and individual nerve roots continue down through the lumbar spine like loose wires in a cable. If something compresses these wires (like a large herniated disc), multiple functions are affected simultaneously - bladder, bowels, legs, and sensation in the 'saddle' area where you'd sit on a horse.
explanation.key_insight: The key to CES is RECOGNIZING IT EARLY. Ask every patient with severe back pain about urinary symptoms, saddle numbness, and bilateral leg symptoms. Urinary RETENTION (can't urinate) is more specific than incontinence. Once bladder function is completely lost, recovery is poor even with surgery - timing is critical.
explanation.technical_details: The conus medullaris ends at L1-L2; below this, only cauda equina nerve roots exist. CES affects S2-S4 roots (bladder, bowel, sexual function, saddle sensation) plus variable lumbar roots (leg weakness/numbness). MRI shows central disc herniation, tumor, abscess, or hematoma compressing nerve roots.

definitions_glossary.cauda_equina: Bundle of lumbar and sacral nerve roots below the conus medullaris (L1-L2)
definitions_glossary.cauda_equina_syndrome: Compression of cauda equina nerve roots causing bowel/bladder/sexual/motor dysfunction
definitions_glossary.saddle_anesthesia: Numbness in perineum, buttocks, and inner thighs (S2-S5 distribution)
definitions_glossary.urinary_retention: Inability to void; painless distended bladder; post-void residual >100-200mL
definitions_glossary.conus_medullaris: Terminal end of spinal cord, typically at L1-L2 level
definitions_glossary.central_disc_herniation: Posterior midline disc protrusion compressing central canal contents
definitions_glossary.complete_CES: Painless urinary retention with overflow incontinence; poorer prognosis
definitions_glossary.incomplete_CES: Urinary difficulties but some preserved function; better prognosis if treated promptly
definitions_glossary.post_void_residual: Volume remaining in bladder after urination; measured by catheterization or ultrasound
definitions_glossary.lower_motor_neuron_signs: Flaccid weakness, hyporeflexia, atrophy; characterizes CES
definitions_glossary.bilateral_radiculopathy: Nerve root dysfunction affecting both legs; distinguishes from unilateral radiculopathy
definitions_glossary.lumbosacral_decompression: Surgical laminectomy and discectomy to relieve cauda equina compression

pathophysiology.mechanism: Compression of the cauda equina nerve roots (L2-S5) in the lumbar spinal canal disrupts motor, sensory, and autonomic innervation to the lower extremities, bladder, bowel, and perineum

anatomy.conus_level: Spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults
anatomy.cauda_equina: L2-S5 nerve roots traveling through lumbar canal to exit at appropriate foramina
anatomy.S2_S4_function: Bladder detrusor, external urethral sphincter, bowel, sexual function

CES_subtypes.incomplete: Urinary difficulties (hesitancy, poor stream) but not retention; better prognosis
CES_subtypes.complete_with_retention: Painless urinary retention with overflow; worse prognosis

diagnostic_imaging.MRI: Gold standard; shows compressive lesion, edema, nerve root compression
diagnostic_imaging.emergency: MRI should be obtained immediately if CES suspected

differential_diagnosis: Conus medullaris syndrome (upper motor neuron signs, earlier sacral involvement)
Spinal cord compression (above L1-L2, upper motor neuron signs)
Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome (ascending weakness, areflexia, CSF protein)

surgical_decompression.timing: Emergent: within 24-48 hours; earlier may be better
surgical_decompression.procedure: Laminectomy with discectomy, tumor resection, or abscess drainage
surgical_decompression.evidence: Surgery within 24 hours associated with better bladder outcomes

non_operative.abscess_consideration: Some epidural abscesses may be treated with IV antibiotics alone if no neurological deficit
non_operative.tumor: May require radiation/chemotherapy after or instead of surgery

prognosis.factors: Duration of symptoms, completeness of CES, timing of surgery
prognosis.bladder_recovery: Most critical determinant of quality of life; often incomplete if delayed

definition.@value: A neurosurgical emergency caused by compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots, presenting with saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and lower extremity weakness, requiring urgent decompression

scopeNote.@value: Covers recognition, diagnosis, and emergent management of cauda equina syndrome

learning_objectives: Recognize red flag symptoms of cauda equina syndrome in patients with back pain
Differentiate CES from conus medullaris syndrome and radiculopathy
Order appropriate emergent imaging (MRI lumbar spine)
Explain the importance of surgical timing for outcome
Describe the expected recovery trajectory after decompression
clinical_pearls: Ask EVERY severe back pain patient about bladder, bowels, and saddle numbness
Urinary RETENTION is more specific than incontinence for CES
Incomplete CES has better prognosis - operate before progression to complete CES
Surgery within 24 hours associated with better bladder outcomes
common_misconceptions: Incontinence is the key symptom - RETENTION is more specific and concerning
Back pain must be severe - may be relatively mild with prominent leg/bladder symptoms
Any bladder symptom = CES - must have constellation of findings
